Recommendation to receive supporting doc: 'speaker_1': 'Report from City Manager Parks, Recreation and Marine. Recommendation to receive supporting documentation under the record. Conclude the public hearing and adopt a resolution amending the master fee and charges schedule by adopting a public sea wall. Mooring Lease Permit Fee.'
'speaker_1': 'That's the first item.'
'speaker_0': 'Thank you. Have to turn this over to staff.'

'speaker_6': 'Thank you, Mr. Mayor. Members of the City Council. I'll be handling the staff report for this item. So when the city was required to or when the city put together the Naples Seawall program, it was an investment in our public sea walls.'

'speaker_6': 'And we went to the Coastal Commission to gain approval. The Coastal Commission put a number of requirements on the project. One of them is to create a new lease program for the private use of public waterways in the city of Long Beach, specifically as it deals with the Naples area.'

'speaker_6': 'There are six phases of the Naples Improvement Project. What we're really going to be talking about tonight is a program that will be created as we improve those various areas of the Naples Sea walls, creating a new fee structure for compensating the public for use of that of that space by a private entity.'

'speaker_6': 'And it really is designed to only affect the areas of the sea walls where the city is investing and creating a new sea wall. So what you have in front of you tonight is a new proposed lease agreement, which is, in a sense, a fee and will be replacing the current fee that we have for that that'

'speaker_6': 'users, private homeowners are currently paying for their docks. I want to talk a little bit about what that structure looks like, what the process was that we went through and give you an idea of what the magnitude is of this fee.'

'speaker_6': 'So as we went through to create this proposed lease program to adhere to the Coastal Commission's requirement, we use the following criteria. We want to make sure this program will only affect those properties where new public seawalls are installed.'

'speaker_6': 'We're designing this program so that the average user will pay approximately what they're currently paying. The new new lease program should generate at least the same amount of revenue as the current fees. We did a lot of surveys to look, to see, to make sure that the program is pricing is going to be competitive.'

'speaker_6': 'Looking at the neighbors in the Naples area, looking at public private, looking at city of Newport Beach, looking at other market conditions, and a program will generate revenue that will cover costs associated with operations, repair and maintenance. We've had three public meetings gone out and spoke to the community about this new fee program, an ad and explaining'

'speaker_6': 'that the old fee is being replaced by this new fee. To give you a magnitude of what the fee will look like currently, the the average fee, we looked at five different properties to determine an average fee. That average fee is about $205 a year.'

'speaker_6': 'The new average fee, when we look at those five properties, three properties actually see a slight decrease. One sees a slight increase of about $8 and the other who had no boat before, which is now this is about a fee that is for the entire use of the dock rather than just a boat parking at a dock'

'speaker_6': 'that sees an increase. And so with that, the new average will be about $215 as opposed to $205. So we believe that this is a very equitable arrangement. It's very similar to what we have today. And we'll be rolling out this lease program in as we do additional seawall investments unless otherwise directed by the Coastal Commission or'
'speaker_6': 'by the Council. And with that, that I stand by to answer questions and we have our team here as well to answer more specific questions.'
'speaker_4': 'Councilmember Price.'

'speaker_5': 'Thank you. Well, first of all, thank you very much to your entire team. So Rachel Tanner and Eric Lopez. I consider us a team in this project. And for those who don't know, this team has been incredibly successful at facilitating a 1900 linear feet.'

'speaker_5': 'More than 1900 linear feet. Redo of the public seawalls in Naples from the Revo Alto Canal, the from the Ravenna Bridge to the eastern portion of the Toledo Bridge. The project has been on schedule, on budget, and I go out there and do periodic site visits, and I'm incredibly impressed with how efficient that team has been.'

'speaker_5': 'So first and foremost, for such a huge project that is very unique in its components. These these seawalls are incredibly unique. We have nothing like them anywhere else in the city. They're unique to the state, in fact, and the manner that the seawalls were actually put into place, the whole instrumentation was unique and tried out for the'

'speaker_5': 'first time here. And I expect that after we finish phase one, we'll do a little presentation for my colleagues and and the public in terms of what went into the installation of these seawalls, but is an incredibly impressive operation.'

'speaker_5': 'So I want to thank the team for being there. And most importantly, I want to thank you for the outreach that you've done with the community. As as the staff knows, outreach is it's very, very important to me.'

'speaker_5': 'I think sometimes the best ideas get lost in the mix if you don't have sufficient outreach with the public. So thank you. This dock item is one such example. So I just want to ask a few questions before we as we move through the the presentation tonight.'

'speaker_5': 'The first is and this is probably addressed to Mr. Modica. Is it accurate that the fees that were mandated by Coastal Commission only apply to the phase of the Seawall project that's just been completed?'

'speaker_6': 'So if I remember the Coastal Commission recommendation or the condition they asked for it to be for the area of improvement for the entire Naples seawall or at the very minimum, the Naples phase one. When we put this program together, staff is recommending to just begin with the areas where this where the work is actually being done'

'speaker_6': '. So there's a nexus between the new program and the actual construction work being done. That certainly can change in the future with future phases, but that's how we're approaching it.'
'speaker_5': 'And right now, as it stands today, the fees apply only to those who have who are utilizing the space in phase one.'

'speaker_6': 'That's correct. You only get charged a fee and you and the new lease will occur when you reinstall your dock onto the public seawall. If you choose not to install the dock, there will be no fee.'
'speaker_5': 'Now, some have speculated, you know, what happens in the future. Could this be applied to other areas in Naples? That's not an issue that's within the city's control. Is that correct?'

'speaker_6': 'It actually could be a city council decision should you choose it. We are doing this upon a condition from the Coastal Commission, so that's really why we have to do this phase. We could certainly we're charging fees today.'

'speaker_6': 'This is a different way to compensate for for public use. And it may come to a point in the future where the Coastal Commission requires it and everything else. But right now we are we are choosing or at least the recommendation before you is to do this section.'
'speaker_5': 'Okay. So the mandate that's requiring us to recalculate the fees is a mandate that came from Coastal Commission, which is a statewide entity and not the city of Long Beach.'
'speaker_6': 'That is correct.'

'speaker_5': 'Okay. So in terms of future application or future mandates and in terms of other areas, that's certainly something that the city could look at. But if it were to be a Coastal Commission mandate, it would come from the Coastal Commission.'
'speaker_6': 'That is correct.'
'speaker_5': 'Okay. And then in terms of the fees, we're talking here about a fee of an average of $215 a year, is that right?'
'speaker_6': 'Yes, that's correct.'
'speaker_5': 'Now, what about future fees? How how would the issue be assessed in the future in terms of lease renewals and what the fee will be in the future once the lease is up for renewal?'

'speaker_6': 'So this fee is going to be in our master fee and charges schedule. The way it will work is we will sign a five year lease with the property owner, which will define what the fee is, how it's calculated.'

'speaker_6': 'But the actual rate will be considered by the council as part of the master fee and charges schedule every single year. Our master fee and charges policy from the Council is that we apply a CPI increase. So there is some when they sign the lease, they'll know what the fee is in that year and it will be'
'speaker_6': 'subject to review in the future by the council, you know, should they choose to increase it or modify it in some way.'

'speaker_5': 'Is it fair to assume, though, that our process for determining whether or not there will be a fee increase will be the same process we use for fee increases throughout the city, for other uses of fees such as fees for the marina, etc..'

'speaker_6': 'Absolutely would be the same process and frankly, it's very similar to the process that has been in effect for for 15, 20 years. As we assess the current fee, that is also a fee that is reviewed by the Council as part of the master fees and schedule master.'
'speaker_6': 'If he's in charge of schedule every single year.'

'speaker_5': 'And then in terms of the lease renewal, is there going to be anything unusual about the terms of the lease or requirements for the lease renewal or anything that people should be on notice on now in anticipation of the lease renewal?'
'speaker_5': 'Or do we expect that the lease would be renewal barring anything unforeseen?'

'speaker_6': 'I believe it's the latter. It's there's a number of conditions that, you know, if that were determined to be where you were in violation of your lease, if you're operating in an unsafe manner for example and if we need to Alveda Helen and can explain what those are.'

'speaker_6': 'But barring that we've actually attached a sample copy of the lease in the agenda item today that's very similar to what we'll be asking everyone, one to sign and they'll see the agreement before they sign it.'

'speaker_5': 'Thank you. I know that I personally would not want to be dealing with Alveda on a violation of any because she means business. She's very nice, but she means business and I appreciate that consistency in business. So anyway, thank you very much.'
'speaker_5': 'I have no additional questions. Thank you, Mr. Mayor.'

'speaker_6': 'And one thing I'd like to point out, Councilmember, if I may, part of what was requested is that we go out and do three different community meetings and talk about it and the feedback we heard the most. Once they understood what the fee was, was to include something in the lease to help tell future homeowners that there'

'speaker_6': 'are restrictions on the size of the boat. And we thought that that was a very good suggestion. And that's been incorporated into the leases that they know where to look for, that there is a restriction on the size of the boats that can be docked and can be safely navigated through the channels.'
'speaker_6': 'So that's been included.'

'speaker_0': 'Thank you very much. LOWENTHAL Do you have any comment? Okay. We have a motion any second on the first part of the motions or any public comment for this part of the motion hearing. CNN members, please go out and cast your votes.'
'speaker_1': 'Seven votes. Yes.'

'speaker_0': 'Okay. And I'll hopefully take a motion for the second part of the vote. Okay. There's a motion any second. Is there any public comment on the second part of the hearing? CNN. Please cast your votes.'

MODICA Even if we had the $103 million for the pool right now, is there any part of the project that we could start that we are not already engaged in?'

'speaker_6': 'No. We have still need to go through a number of steps before we can begin actual construction. We are currently in the design process working on conceptual and schematic design. 'speaker_6': 'We need to go through the entitlement process at a city level. We need to go through the Coastal Commission entitlement process. 'speaker_6': 'least, if we were to go incredibly quickly with that process.'

'speaker_5': 'Now with money in hand, could we phase this project in any way other than it's currently phase, such as, for example, we're going through the design process now. Beyond that, is there any phasing of this project that could occur if we had the money in hand today?'

'speaker_6': 'So we've looked at that and to see is are there segments of the pool that could be phase because we've done that with other projects. The Alamitos Bay Marina, for example, we've done in several phases because it's such a large project.'

'speaker_6': 'The difference there is that that has discrete sections that you can isolate from all the other sections so that you can repair those work on that section, and when the money is exhausted, you can stop work and then go on to the next one.'

'speaker_6': 'The pool that we are envisioning is trying to fit in a very tight space so that we're being cognizant of the the residents and of the cost. And we really do not see an ability to be able to phase the pool without having to shut down access to the bodies of water.'
'speaker_6': 'And we really want to keep bodies of water available to the public. And so we don't see an opportunity for phasing on this project.'

'speaker_5': 'Okay. So, I mean, what what I want to make clear is that the pool is a major priority for this council. 'speaker_5': 'budget. So the pool is definitely a high priority, but we do have a $43 million gap to get the pool to the place where it's fully funded, correct?'
'speaker_6': 'Yes, we have in total $60.1 million set aside with 43 left to be funded.'

'speaker_5': 'So if we were to hear in the community, people say, you know, if you if you had the money, if you funded the pool today, we could start the pool sooner. That actually is just a factually inaccurate statement because we can't start the pool any sooner.'

'speaker_6': 'Yes, that's correct.'

'speaker_5': 'Okay. So in regards to the pool, you know, there have been some suggestions in regards to moving around some of the. The $43 million has already been allocated to the pool. The remaining money from the 95 million, some have said, well, could you allocate another million or 2 million or 3 million to the pool?'

'speaker_5': 'And looking at some of our projects, you know, one a 1 to $3 million range can fund a lot of our smaller projects because we have projects that need to be funded as low as in the mid 100,000 range to a half a million dollar range is where most of our projects seem to be.'
'speaker_5': 'I'm looking at the list. Does that sound about right?'

'speaker_6': 'Yes. And that was one of the prioritization criteria is to try to get a balance of projects, realizing that all of the money could go to one or two projects and wait until you're ready to actually do them.'
'speaker_6': 'But at the same time, you're losing opportunity to do some very, very needed and critical projects that are smaller dollar amount and important to the stakeholders as well.'
